title: 111_hr4555
content: The "Janey Ensminger Act" provides hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care for veterans stationed at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, during the time when the water was contaminated at the base. Veterans stationed at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, during the period of water contamination are eligible for medical care, regardless of medical evidence linking their illness to the contamination. Family members of these veterans are also covered under the "Janey Ensminger Act." The "Janey Ensminger Act" extends medical care eligibility to family members of veterans stationed at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, during the water contamination period, regardless of evidence linking their illness to the contamination. Covered conditions and disabilities are those described in section 1119(a)(2) of this title. The "Janey Ensminger Act" provides health care for family members of veterans stationed at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, during the water contamination period. It establishes presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with contaminants in the water supply at Camp Lejeune. The "Janey Ensminger Act" establishes presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with contaminants in the water supply at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, under section 1119 of title 38, United States Code. This includes diagnosed or undiagnosed illnesses determined by the Secretary in consultation with the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry. The regulations under this section establish a presumption of service connection for veterans exposed to volatile organic compounds at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina. Illnesses must manifest within a specified period in veterans who served on active duty at the base and were exposed to these compounds. Veterans who served on active duty at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, and have illnesses linked to volatile organic compounds in the water supply are presumed to have been exposed to the compounds unless proven otherwise. The Secretary will establish regulations for a presumption of service connection based on medical evidence of the association between exposure and disease occurrence. The Secretary will establish regulations for a presumption of service connection based on medical evidence of the association between exposure to volatile organic compounds and disease occurrence. In making determinations, the Secretary will consider all sound medical and scientific information, including the statistical significance, replicability, and peer review of studies. An association between a disease and exposure to volatile organic compounds will be considered positive if the credible evidence for the association outweighs the evidence against it. The regulations under this section ensure that veterans and survivors continue to receive compensation and benefits based on the presumption of disease occurrence.
